question: 立てる
sourceAnswer: to{}{stand-up/put-up/set-up/erect/raise} | to{}{thrust-into/bury-into/dig-into} | to{}{make-(a-noise)/start-(a-rumour)/raise-(a-cloud-of-dust,-etc.)/cause} | to{}{make/establish/set-up/develop/formulate} | to{}{put-up-(a-political-candidate)/make-(one's-leader)} | to{}{treat-with-respect/give-(someone)-their-due/make-(someone)-look-good/avoid-embarrassing-(someone)} | to{}{sharpen/make-clear} | to{}{shut/close} | to{}{make-tea-(matcha)/perform-the-tea-ceremony} | to{}divide-by | to{?}do-...-vigorously

sourceMnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" and this means <vocabulary>to stand something up</vocabulary>. It also can mean <vocabulary>to make something</vocabulary>, both in a physical sense, like making a sound, and a mental sense, like making a plan. 

Don't confuse this with <ja>立つ</ja>. <ja>立てる</ja> means that you're standing something up. As in, "I stood up the action figure" or "I will erect the flag." You're doing the action to something else.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the <ja>た</ja> portion. In order to do that, think of yourself standing up a huge sign. On it, written in big words:
"<reading>ta</reading> ta (<ja>た</ja>)!"
